            reducers must always follow some special rules:

            • They should only calculate the new state value based on the state and action arguments
            • They are not allowed to modify the existing state. Instead, they must make immutable updates, by copying the existing state and making changes to the copied values.
            • They must not do any asynchronous logic or other â€œside effectsâ€

            why are these rules important?

            • One of the goals of Redux is to make your code predictable. When a functionâ€™s output is only calculated from the input arguments, itâ€™s easier to understand how that code works, and to test it.
            • On the other hand, if a function depends on variables outside itself, or behaves randomly, you never know what will happen when you run it.
            • If a function modifies other values, including its arguments, that can change the way the application works unexpectedly. This can be a common source of bugs, such as â€œI updated my state, but now my UI isnâ€™t updating when it should!â€
            • Some of the Redux DevTools capabilities depend on having your reducers follow these rules correctly.

            Remember: reducer functions must always create new state values immutably, by making copies! Itâ€™s safe to call mutating functions like Array.push() or modify object fields like state.someField = someValue inside of createSlice(), because it converts those mutations into safe immutable updates internally using the Immer library, but donâ€™t try to mutate any data outside of createSlice!
